Both bilateral and rotational symmetry are properties of an efficient and healthy natural being. That’s why geometers across cultures have encoded these properties into the design of art and architecture. One could say that humans create objects that reflect an ideal natural state, or at least subconsciously desire so. This implies a link between the human subconscious mind and a perfect world. It shows that everyone has the potential to create perfection within their minds. It tells us that we should embrace that ability. Let all sons and daughters craft their art. Through this, we reveal what is most sacred within us: the desire for beauty, the drive for a harmony between our optimized self and environment.

So happy I stumbled upon this excellent analysis. One of the things I have always wondered is exactly this. I specifically ask myself why certain districts in a city elevate your mood and some do the opposite. Why in so many movies and stories do we see youth who hate their hometown and would leave it behind at the first opportunity? I have entertained such questions with a pragmatic ambition: would it not be so beneficial to whole societies if we learned how to intervene and change the "beauty" factor? Wouldn't you like to have cities and rural areas where most places are beautiful? And the ripple effect of having more and more content and happy citizens is all positive as well.

It pains me to see what the potentials for us, as a civilization, are and what world we live in. What we could be is worlds farther from what the reality is in Kharkiv and Mariupol and Kiev and Yemen and Kabul ...

A thing of Beauty is a joy forever, it's loveliness increases, it will never pass into nothingness.

While I really like your way of talking of these subjects, and I admire your appreciation for beauty, the "why" isn't really well discussed, and is entirely non-sensical if you don't take our necessity for a transcendent purpose into account, and that of humanity's relationship with the divine. I understand that to an atheist this sounds like hogwash, but I think that we can at least agree that there is a huge mystery in how humanity has developed to actually be conscious of the universe that surrounds it, and that it appreciates beauty to a degree that no other creature does.

I'm currently what I'd call a personal agnostic, in so far as I've never experienced something that makes me think that God is definitely real, but at the same time am a practicing Catholic. This actually isn't contradictory, because the experience of multiple people has shown that God (supposedly) doesn't make himself known to all people from the moment they are conscious. It is a process of discovery, in some cases more sudden than others. The Catholic Faith doesn't actually teach that you can't have your doubts, it teaches only that those doubts shouldn't be driven by rebellion and pride, and that they should be motivated by a genuine desire to find truth. That is what it teaches. Whether it's what its followers have done in the past is a different issue.

My point, though, is that to understand the "why" of beauty, and to trully appreciate beauty to a much higher degree, you would need to also take into account the possibility that beauty might actually be an expression of God's love for his people. It is a gift, as well as a reflection of Himself. When nature is seen as a gift out of love for you, whenever you experience beauty, you will also feel loved.

So if, like me, you haven't felt God's presence; you could always ask. There is no harm in asking for that faith. I haven't experienced it myself, but my father (a previously very skeptical person before his sudden religious experience) did, and I trust him enough to give it a try.

Felt this in the gut having been born in a third-world country in a semiurban "city" which barely classifies as one in a state that is mostly rural and wilderness, and now live in the capital of another third-world country; both of them in South America.

My home was a low income neighbor surrended (like 99% of building in the whole region) by blocky boring old unispired structures. In my neighbor just like in most of my state (except the wealthier ones where houses were made by actual contractors that used a model by an architect, for example; and usually foreigners) the houses were painted by their owners without regard of harmony or color palette. Awful mismatched houses. Most of them without finished walls, bare concrete block, just a totally utilitarian view of life because we have a culture were if you are living in poverty then you cannot worry about aesthetic, urbanism, balance.

So lots of road because it had two of the biggest refineries you can get in the world, but that made my already desertic hot state even more hotter. Lots of building and roads trapping heat in the ground, very few plants and trees = a living hell. Then there was zero education in disposing trash, so the parts where nature was unconquered it was filled with cactus that trapped every plastic bag throwed away by inconsiderate pricks, which were the majority of the people living there. So when one had the chance to see a natural wild panoramic view it was filled with ugly plastic that reminded you why you hated your own people. It doesn't cost money to just store the plastic bags and throw it away in any fucking trash can. No excuses there, just trashy people with trashy culture.

God I hated that place. Felt miserable everyday. Everybody happy to used every penny buying cheap imitations of designer brands, customizing cars (making them even uglier and trashy), buying loud sound speakers to put reggaeton all fucking day and not having even a slight consideration for their neighbors but never worrying about their surroundings. You are born in a place like that, and have an ounce of aesthetic sense and you feel as an outsider very quickly. You want to get out before that society swallows you.

On top of that there was this insidious culture of everybody wanting to be more "cunning" and "astute" than their the guy next to them, always trying to one-up every sentence, always mocking other people and each other, always trying to swindle and gain something out of every interaction. Viveza criolla is what we call it. And it's endemic of Spanish conquered cultures. So combining a celebration of ignorance and anti-intelectuallism, mocking book-readers and embracing pure short-sighted goals and you get people more worried about vacuous things than the real actual problems. Of course sleazy politicians, leaders, pseudo-doctors, simoniacs and televangelist are very popular there. A breeding ground of stupid motherfuckers that sociophats with good oratory skills can scam.

As a country we let populist and demagoges dictate our fates because MONEYMONEY easy money, oil-rentism, and lazyness to research and make those scammers accountable. And a long history of military strong-men dictating the fate of our lives and getting presidential seats. And lots of military coups too. So a (on the paper) richer countries of the region, now is one of the poorest and high violent criminal rates of the world, with zero freedom and a high proportion of journalist imprisoned, and opposition political prisoners. We are fucked. All done by stupid ignorant idiots wanting that easy money and revanchism.

...

Now I live in a capital in another third-world country after escaping that hellhole.

Where I live is basically a suburb surrounding the central historic area. In the actual historic central capital the buildings have a colonial beautiful (but decadent) Spanish aesthetic and it's really eye-pleasing. Althought still sad that many of those historical architecture is being abandoned and not enought effort is put to recover them. I get that there are many problems in the country, but if you are not a stupid imbecile you know there is always enough money for that kind of reconstruction. I'ts just that corruption in the lawmakers, governors and contractors always impedes that. So those 400-500 hundred years old building are falling appart.

But here where I actually live in a more residential area every homeowner is worried about making money (can't blame them) and making their usually boring blocky houses into 3,4 or more story buildings apartments to rent and make a living out of that. Not gonna get into he safety issues (this country is very active in earthquakes) because that sole reason should be enough to detract any intelligent living soul on the enterprises this middle class homeowners are doing.

So they build on top of the houses, multiplying the uglyness.

It means quality of living is shitty: constant noise contamination (machinery, hammering, drillings.... it's maddening), ugly surroundings because a stupid law taxes owners extra if the non-frontal walls are finished and extremely crammed houses all together. Feels like an overcrowed rat maze. In my area are some green parks, which is nice, but doesn't compensate for the "concrete jungle" feeling I get here, specially when there is not a single building with a nice architecture design. It's way better than the place were I come from, because most houses are "nice" althought uninspired which is compared to my old home town, but still...

Cannot wait enough to GTFO of here, go to a more wealthy area where the whole Pacific is in the horizon, parks and plazas are more beautiful and well designed, with sculptures made by artists, with calm people contemplating the sunset while walking their dogs. Other people doing yoga, other dancing, etc. It's a dream!

And it's not a matter of being poor or wealthy. I always thought about this, and Asians among other cultures understand very well this: you can live in abject fucking poverty, but every human DESERVES beauty. And it's not a matter of money. Ugly things can be modified and rearranged to be more pleasant to our senses. It's not about money. But short-sightness and lack of education (not prioritized by the state) or a pure utilitarian industrialist curriculum is what has made us this hollow unhappy conformist zombies. You can transform your surroundings with zero money! But it requires having another mentality, and thats difficult for trash tacky people.

And I think us the low income, blue collar or customer service workers, the grinders, need more beauty than anyone in his planet. Beauty to relief our stress, anxiety and depression. I'm not the crazy one that is asking for impossible superficial shiny things. No, I'm always demanding a better life for our communities.This should be a fucking human right!

But, only undeveloped nations have concrete, not detailed houses and boring city landscapes. Countries like Emirate, France, Italy or Singapore make beautiful and green structures that make us happy and pleased with our surroundings.

This honestly is one of my favourite videos you guys have made. I've quite recently finally connected the dots. The circumstances on my life have been very good. I won't go too much into detail but in general I have everything I need. And a lot of things I want. But I still feel really depressed for some reason. I will be soon moving out of my apartment and one idea where I would move would be my summer cottage, I had other options but they were much more expensive so I rather did not take them. So I went there for a week to prepare for me to move in and testing how feasible is living there. I enjoyed the time there, I was much less comfortable there yeah since it lacks most modern comforts. But I was happy there. Once I returned to my dull concrete box of a apartment I immediately felt my mood drop. It was like a train hit me. A few days later i thought about it and realised most likely it's the environment that's causing this. At that moment I realized, no matter how much modern comforts I have no matter how much material belongings I have, no matter how much money I have I will never have a happy life if I live in a ugly environment.
To anyone reading this: You make me Recover 2 days earlyer on average

Yesterday I was doing my runs for my job at an armored truck company. Over the past weekend I've just been unusually down in the dumps, feeling depressed, feeling genuinely awful. It was so bad I had to call out on Saturday--and I only do a 3-4 day week. Hours are long to make up for it, but still. I felt so dreadful and unable to sleep that I was sincerely unsafe to drive at one point because of it, so I stayed home.

But when I drove yesterday, it's a weird route because of labor day. A lot of places are closed. I was taken along a heavily wooded rural road with no cars on it, and I just remember how awestruck I was by the beautiful scenery and how weirdly good it made me feel--like all the terrible feelings I'd been having the past few days just suddenly went away as inexplicably as they came.

I have been doing some personal thought experiments over the past 12 years as a form of mental exercise to form my own standards of reasons, and here are a couple points in summary of those findings that I have as of yet observed;

1. Our productivity as a society constitutes of 3 general areas; a person's Vision of their self, Knowledge they utilise, and the place and people they Network with.

2. It's the evolution of our own biological self preservation mechanism shaped by the reaction to the lifestyle we choose to live in, like how our ancestors have done in the past (can sustain one's self, can survive).

3. Our conscious (perception) and subconscious (attention) habits of our lifestyle to the environment we live in shapes the circumstances that we are in; ie. how satisfied we are.

4. That satisfaction, expectation, risk-to-reward, etc that we continue to adjust and prepare for is a natural (personal circumstances) and nurtured (parent and cultural influence) decision, depending on how competent we are as an individual.

5. Skill, understanding, awareness, adaptability to our surroundings is a mix of what we desire to be and where our influences are from, with better influences often preparing and raising better results.


This is just a fraction of many aspects I have been picking bits and pieces of, thanks in part to videos like these that are made and events that have unfolded over the years. The only difference between my observations and the depth of research done by the experts in these fields are large, so my focus is more on how average people like me can get the best results from the influences that they can be around.

Being an artist with BDD, this is in part why its so hard to live with myself. I appreciate beauty like anyone else, but I have a bit more of an eye for detail and understand its importance in our life. To walk around every day knowing that the body you inhabit entirely changes the way people see you, how they feel around you, and to be able to describe exactly every detail thats wrong and needs altering, but cant do so... Its miserable. I want to take someones breath away. Sometimes I look at someone and notice a particularly unique and beautiful curvature of their lips, or notice they have a nice color to their skin that makes them a work of art, and I know that no one will ever feel that type of intrigue and joy when they look at me. Something about being ugly sort of feels like you disrupt the environment around you. you People want to be away from ugly things. And of course there is the extra layer of men being "visual creatures", so romantic relationships are different. They dont cherish you and bathe in your presence when youre dull and misshapen, artistically and aesthetically off-putting, drab. They might learn to love other things, but no one will ever look at me longingly or treat me like a goddess because my beauty inspires them to. This is why fashion makes me feel good. I feel like I have a little control over my own beauty, and the way people treat me.

I have meditated upon this.
I consider beauty to be an abstract, subjective, often fleeting appreciation of something.
There are 3 categories of beauty to me:
Sexual beauty: the appreciation of the qualities of another sympathetic being. This means anything that is alive or representative of a living thing. We subconsciously evaluate all living things this way and despite the name it has nothing to do with carnal desire.
Subjective beauty: the appreciation of anything that can be tangibly experienced with one or more senses that is not alive, such as a sunrise, fair weather, good food, or music.
Through the first 2 categories we gain the ability to deeply appreciate the universe around us on a fundamental basal level.
And finally Existential beauty: the appreciation of abstract concepts such as love, compassion, reason, and faith.
Through the latter 2 we gain the ability to appreciate things on an analytical and emotional level.
And thus through all 3 we are human.

I think all these studies only serve to turn something real, which is inherently obvious and relatable, into ambiguous and unconvincing statistics. I don't believe we should put so much importance on data, especially when talking about beauty, happiness, love, and those things which serve as effectively the only reasons we don't all just kill ourselves. Somehow our society has managed to convince itself that feelings are unimportant, which absolutely bewilders me. What is more important than feelings? What reason is there to live aside from feelings? None, I say. Work, obligations, responsibilities, goals. These are all just problems that could be instantly solved by dying. The experience of feelings is the only thing that makes life worth it, and it should be enough for us.

When people find something beautiful, they enjoy observing it. Observing things is how we learn about them. Perhaps beauty is our brain's way of telling us that there's something valuable to be learned from what we're looking at. Simple patterns like the side of a building are boring because we already know everything we need to know about them. Random noise like in a child's drawing is also uninteresting because there's no underlying logic to be understood. So only the complex, intricate, but logic-driven patterns are beautiful to us.

As a professional artist I've given this a fair amount of thought. Beauty is the process of creating a discernable pattern and then breaking that pattern but only far enough to create tension between opposites. The more you can break the pattern without actually breaking the overall pattern the better you are at it. In the end no matter what kind of art it is the final product has to interact with itself in such a way that nothing can be added or taken away without ruining the harmony inside the work. The harmony is the dynamic effect of opposites creating tensions in ways that go round and round. Music exists in time. Painting in a space. Literature in patterns of meaning. They all depend on composition. It has to do with how our brains work, probably because of the kind of patterns we find in nature which are similar to this in effect. I'm sure that wasn't very helpful, sorry I'm not a writer. I think it's a coincidental side effect of our massive ability for pattern recognition.

As a disabled person, this is why I have a difficult time making friends.  Look up the halo effect.  Stop lying to yourself and others that people will be friends with you "just because" and "all you have to do is just be a good person".  If you are aesthetically pleasing, it makes your friends feel good to be around you which attracts more social curiosity.  If you look "weird", even the most well-meaning person will receive outside influence that they "can do better", and will be poached into drifting away from you despite your best efforts.  So if you don't fit the social definitions of beauty, it may be time to consider terminating your consciousness to alleviate the existential pain.

I've been pondering about the reason why beauty is according to most people more important than having a clean or safe city... It's actually pretty obvious. With beauty, safety and cleanliness come almost automatically since something needs to be clean before it can be called beautiful. In this case I refer with 'clean' to the literal meaning of it with junk not all over the place, and being removed instead of piling up somewhere in a corner where it's not in the way, but still visible.

To explain beauty being more important than clean or safe more properly I'll start with the cleanliness of a city. People often start throwing their waste on the street, because it isn't clean anyway which naturally lowers the limit for people to do so as well. This is easy to verify on a very small scale which will apply on a large scale as well: your own bedroom. If it's a mess you won't hold back to stuff something away on a shelve or somewhere on the floor as much as you would do in a clean room. A large scale example of this 'keeping a clean place clean' instinct like thing is one I've read about some years ago (which I still remember for some reason) is used to keep slums in a bit better shape, and to make it easier to improve the situation there. Which is done by painting the houses a bit, so everything would have a tidier appearance to it. Thanks to this the people living there are more likely to keep it cleaner for an extended amount of time, and maybe even start cleaning up whatever garbage is lying around eventually. This also makes it easier for charity organizations to travel around, and get to certain locations a bit faster.

Now for the safety part which holds a strong connection to cleanliness. When your surroundings are beautiful with being clean playing a big part in it the area feels and likely is more orderly. With everything being more clean and orderly you feel safer being there, and with the residents feeling safer they're less prone to perform illegal actions since the area won't feel as dangerous as a messier version of the same area. Therefore they're less likely to act in terms of survival with danger not occupying one's thoughts.

More complex art tends to rely on more subtle patterns and that's why you sometimes need prolonged exposure to tell what's good and what isn't. It always comes down to balance and composition. It's subjective but not unique to every person. It's based on circuitry we all share so there is in deed good and bad art and you can tell the difference. I've always thought about this concept from a more mathematical perspective: Kolmogorov Complexity.

Kolmogorov Complexity defines randomness by how much something can be compressed, or in other words seeing how much it shrinks when you replace a piece of data with instructions on how to build the data. If something is very repetitious, it will be very compressible, as the instructions on how to build it will be much simple than the data itself. On the other hand, if something is very random, it will be very incompressible, as the instructions on how to build it will basically just be a copy of the data.

The interesting thing is that you can use Kolmogorov Complexity to model the amount of useful information contained in a piece of data. If the data is very compressible, then there is not much actual information there (such as with Mary Had a Little Lamb or Do Re Mi Fa So La Ti Do). On the other hand, if the data is very incompressible, then there is a large amount of information, but it is likely to be random rather than useful (such as banging on a keyboard). As humans seek useful information, they are instinctively drawn to data with a Kolmogorov Complexity in the middle of the spectrum, where there exist patterns that indicate the data is not just random noise, but the data is also complex enough to be potentially useful.

If we abandoned modern architecture, I’m sure our cities would be more beautiful, intern creating a more hopeful, happier and confident society to live in. Cities like Köln, Frankfurt, London, Birmingham and Coventry are shells of what beauty existed before, and I think we need to remember that cities were designed for beauty in the past, with designs that existed for the very pursuit of beauty. Ask an architect in the not-so-distant past what architecture was about, they would simply reply “for beauty”. It’s a fact that the symmetry, order, variety and heritage that was contained within these styles of the past made us proud and content with the places we lived in, yet we abandoned our traditions and embraced modern architecture that completely disregarded order, symmetry, ornamentation and heritage (local vernacular) that created unique, beautiful and immortal spaces to live in that would continue for centuries to come. No abstract, post-modern or brutalist building, nor any glass tower can ever create anything as beautiful as the cities we created before, and I think it’s time we embrace the past for what worked and to forget what hasn’t worked.

I completely agree that beauty is important. Beauty and art are amazing and indeed makes us very very happy.


but I don't find the reasoning for how we adopted these feelings convincing because:
Firstly,
- Identifying Fractal patterns to identify certain objects faster doesn't explain why we like them. Our feelings should be neutral since there are dangerous things with Fractal patterns as much as there are safe things with Fractal patterns.
- If identifying things in of itself is rewarding then we should be rewarded all the time but in reality we don't find everything beautiful - it doesn't explain why we sometimes dislike certain colors, shapes, forms, proportions or patterns and sometimes we don't. Like disliking black wall and liking black shirt.


Secondly,
- Asymmetry which means change or different doesn't really always mean bad or danger. It could also mean food or a new object which could be food or useful, that's why humans actually approach asymmetrical things. And we generally like change in our environment.
- If symmetry means safe and asymmetry means danger then we humans are supposed to fear or dislike asymmetrical things which isn't true. We like a lot both symmetrical and asymmetrical shapes.
- Our fears and motivations are usually based on personal experiences and ideas not instinct. for example, no one will consider a deer with impressive antlers to be a nutritious source of food unless he already knows this fact or contemplated it.
- Almost everything in nature is symmetrical. So again, dangerous things could be as symmetrical as safe things. So our feelings should be neutral.
- If asymmetry means danger and is identified quickly for that reason and we get rewarded for symmetry because it means safe and that things are as they should be then an environment with the most symmetry, stable, bland characteristics (like the buildings we dislike) should be considered beautiful
- And if identifying change is what's rewarding then we shouldn't be rewarded for seeing the same things over and over again but we still like beautiful things even if it's repetitive with no change such as a tree in front of your window.


I honestly don't think evolution has anything to do with human perception of beauty at all.


- If it's due to evolutionary history (like for example, since our ancestors across millions of years identified that black water is dangerous, so we dislike black water and consider it ugly. And since they identified that clear water is safe and important, so we like and consider it beautiful.) then we should share this sense of beauty with other animals who needed to survive as much as humans and in fact has survived much longer but has not adopted an interest in symmetrical things rather naturally and logically they appear to respond to stimulus, preservation, instinct, utility and habit which truly give them an advantage and actually makes them survive.
- Seeing something safe and useful or dangerous is important, but beautiful or ugly doesn't help survival. We can find something extremely ugly but we know that it's safe and useful, and we can fear something and find it beautiful, like a colorful snake for example. We also find useless things "beautiful" like a desert or birds or rocks. Plus "ugly" environment causes depression as you said. It's actually a disadvantage than an advantage.
- We also can't say we like certain things because they resemble good things. Many shapes we make that we like or dislike aren't really rooted in nature and are significantly different and don't resemble nature at all.
- There isn't any survival reason to adopt this identification skill into our life by spending seriously significant, huge amounts of time making everything around us symmetrical beautiful, such humans won't have any specific advantage that makes them survive better.


- Why does a group of mindless atoms "want" to "survive" and "like" things in the first place :P

You guys do a great job when it comes to anything quantifiable where empirical data is really the only thing to be able to determine and explain certain things. When it comes to qualitative statements about human and cultural values however your videos often come shockingly short and seem ideologically charged and ethnocentric. I think the exploration of the value and impact of beauty are well expressed. The source of beauty being in fractals and symmetry is pretty far off the mark. Fractals and symmetry may be part of beautiful objects, in limited cases, but they don't define it. Even the example in the video has symmetrical brutalist architecture as an example of soul-deadening ugliness, not beauty. And beyond the shared feature of a trunk, trees are by nature asymmetrical, even pines and redwoods are very asymmetrical in their features. Sunsets and starfields are almost the very definition of asymmetry. Roiling storm clouds and a wave tossed ocean have fractals at a level of imperceptible detail, there appears to be more seduction in chaotic systems. Masterpieces of art by definition avoid symmetry - Leonardo's works approach the subjects from angles and poses with an explicit rejection of symmetry - the Renaissance was born out of a rejection of Medieval rules of symmetrical composition. Applying fractals to Jackson Pollock just shows a lack of attention to his work - or an attempt to force a point that has no support. I think the compulsion by theorists to align beauty with utility is missing the whole point. The mystery of beauty is based on the fact that non-utilitarian experiences have a powerful impact on the human psyche. Which undermines any sort of darwinian approach to understanding beauty. It is the contradiction that states the problem, and simplistic examples of primitive art ignore the examples that invalidate that entire approach - Lascaux and Chauvet Cave paintings anyone?

A good example of standardisation vs expression are the cities of Europe and the US, particularly the cities founded around the time of the industrial revolution

Take a look at the old city centre of any European city, and the buildings are very varied and come with a lot of interesting features. This is because construction was not a standardised thing during the early lifetimes of these cities, and buildings were built how the person who wanted them constructed wanted them built. As a result, we ended up with cramped convoluted city scapes with lots of narrow streets and alleys

Now take a look at a city like say New York, or Los Angeles, and the difference is as clear as night and day, in fact, New York is a sort of missing link between a city like London or Paris, and a city like Los Angeles. New York has a few remnants from the cities of Europe, but for the most part is designed around neat orderly blocks of buildings spaced at regular intervals, and Los Angeles even more so

Why?

Answer, because New York and Los Angeles didn’t grow wild as it were, the growth of cities like London and Paris, while there were people organising it, did not have a unified organisation. Noble comes along and is like, ‘I want a cathedral here’, bunch of peasants come along and say, ‘we need more housing’, the city council finds a random plot of land, gives them some resources and says ‘Knock yourselves out fellas’. The growth was organic, as needed, there was no forward planning of ‘okay, this goes here, that goes there’

Meanwhile, New York and Los Angeles did have this organisation, and while New York’s wasn’t quite to the level that Los Angeles was, it still got the job done, plots were divided up and evenly spaced (don’t ask me why this was as I have no idea the reason behind this), so when it came time to expand the housing, people knew exactly where to build and how much they could, there was structure to the cities growth, and over time, this structure became standardised, why, because it made construction easier, and what happens when you make things easier, you make it cheaper

In a universe where there are never enough resources to do absolutely everything, tasks must be prioritized. Making things symmetrical (whether through biological or technological means) requires extra effort, thus indicating that its symmetry must be important for the thing to work well. (even a decorative vase is less likely to fall over and break if it's symmetrical and balanced.) Things that work well may be extremely useful to us, or extremely dangerous to us; hence, we have an instinct to look for symmetries that indicate what a thing's function might be, so we can evaluate its usefulness and/or its threat to us. We like using our instincts, because they will nonetheless pester us constantly when they go unused.

Drama, mystery, intrigue, and suspense are important elements of what humans find particularly beautiful in all forms of the arts: painting, architecture, literature, music. We are driven to solve mysteries. We constantly ask ourselves: „What is over the next hill?“, „What is inside that box?“ —Be that „hill“ the other side of a mountain, the moon, or another galaxy, and that „box“ a cave, our own minds, or the inside of an atom.
A painting of a placid lake may bring about a feeling of calmness and peace, a welcome therapeutic repass from a hectic world, but a painting of a turbulent storm at sea awakens in us feelings of passion and romance that can inspire us unto new adventure.
I think that all this is derived from a primary success strategy that we inherited long ago from our primate ancestors and deeper down into the animal kingdom. It is our deeply rooted propensity to be curious, to push the boarders of our experience, despite the inherent dangers, in the unknown. Boredom, status, stagnation are agonizing for our souls and can be experienced as being worse to us than physical pain. Our brains actually begin to die when deprived of novel stimulation. We are natural born explorers and it is this unrelenting pursuit of the novel against caution and fear that has reaped the benefits from all our discoveries. It is the monkey who climbs farther up the tree, risking falling, who reaches untapped fruit. It is the explorer who crosses dangerous seas who discovers new territories, cultures, methods, ideas and resources. It is the scientist asking: „Why do apples fall?“, „Why do we get sick?“, „How do birds fly?“, that has given us physics, medicine, and aviation. Individuals may perish in this dangerous and unrelenting search for the new and as yet undiscovered, but nature does not concern herself with individuals— it is the benefits to the group that sustains our species. In art and beauty we find a reflection of ourselves. The enjoyable emotions of contemplating beauty is nature’s way of rewarding us for looking for, creating and supporting order and meaning in our lives and environment— for our psychic and physical survival as human beings is dependent on that quest.

This makes me think, that in a retirement community, changing the artwork on the walls of one home to another might make an old person's time less stressful. Or maybe moving patients from one room to another with progressively beautiful art work on the walls would, more or less, "enjoy" the time they have to spend there. In this video i find a lot of things interesting. First and foremost is the possibility of monetizing the beauty in older people's lives. The amount of older people in the world is increasing at an amazing rate due to better healthcare and medicine. Thus inevitably leading to better and proper care of our elders. Meaning there is a HUGE market for helping the elderly. Maintaining beauty in the world of the elderly might lend itself to happier patients and possibly patients with lots of money helping you.

Edit1: Think of it like reorganizing your room or completely changing the furniture. This has a positive effect on the homeowner,, they like the space (space being the "new" room) more than the old layout and furniture that they had grown used to. I don't know about you but the cleaner or fresher my room is the more happy I am (slightly) . However I do understand that an elderly person with constantly changing surroundings might be unsettling and unfamiliar, which is not really a good thing. So I am perplexed on the issue.

If you go out in nature and look at things, it seems like everything's a fractal which renders the word somewhat meaningless.  A mountain doesn't have to be symmetric in order to be beautiful.  Some things we find beautiful are things that we had to pay attention to in the past.  10,000 years ago, navigation was mostly by landmark.  There are point landmarks such as mountain peaks and line landmarks such as rivers and roads.  Example of a line landmark: You could leave home and walk upstream in the morning, turn around and walk downstream and end up at your house.  In addition, there were animals, both predators and prey that we had to keep an eye on.

As strange as it is I don't feel like this applies to me. This isn't a "special snowflake" statement -- though it might be depending on whether you classify mutative deviations from the norm as such or not -- but rather an observation that this might be most applicable to extroverted brains, and least applicable to autistic brains.

I can find asymmetry appealing. I'm drawn to horror aesthetics like what people would think of as especially "ugly" werewolves, monstrous vampire bats, et cetera. I like certain kinds of gothic architecture which is unappealing to the norm, and I'm not too bothered by brutalist architecture beyond the observation that there isn't much visual variety. I absolutely enjoy variety, often more than my peers, though my feelings on brutalist architecture are more informed by my tolerance for repetition than anything else. It still doesn't depress me, as such, but it does make one long for more chaotic design.

The presented argument seems to be that brutalist architecture isn't appealing due to some standards of beauty. I mean, yes, it's not the most appealing to me but it really is purely down to a repetitive factor. I find interest in much more than most do -- I've found -- when it comes to aesthetics. There's usually some herdthink going on with beauty and aesthetics, as the video has observed. However, I think as much of this is cultural due to extroverted herd behaviour as it is anything else.

An example of this is the changing beauty standards foisted upon women ranging from the stick body with boobs, to the hourglass figure, to finally the "thicc" look. This shows a decreasing emphasis on breasts and an increasing one on hips. This is more informed by social norms which happen in waves; once a social norm wave has begun it spreads across all extroverted herds ensuring conformity. Extroverts don't wish to speak out against affiliated herds in case that causes them to lose social status.

As such, often, I believe that beauty is defined by Dark Triad groups who excel at modifying the behaviour of extroverted herds. They're good at pushing their view through enough and to enough extroverts that it becomes a new social norm wave, spreading across all extroverted herds until that becomes the new "Normal." As we see with the changing body standards foisted upon women, Q.E.D.

Therefore I don't think that beauty is as complex, layered, or mystical as it's laid out to be, here. I think it really is as simple as a certain manifestation of geometry appealing to members of a Dark Triad group, which then spreads throughout the herds.

There are parts of the world where the wave regarding female human beauty standards haven't hit, and they're still operating on hourglass as the superior body model. Eventually this will be eradicated and will stand until whatever comes next. This is why people agree on beauty, it's conformism and people doing what they're told to do, and thinking what they're told to think.

On a similar note, you have the Apple logo. Aesthetic, or simply manipulation of extroverted herd behaviour? I'd say the latter, because a study comparing the response of religious individuals to religious imagery activated the same areas of the brain as when Apple fans looked at an Apple logo. I don't see the beauty in it, myself, because it's a simplistic abstraction of an Apple and thus not particularly special to me.

However, this is clearly not true for Apple fans who see the logo as a testament to something, and thus an evident beauty -- to them.

I've long doubted the idea of Universal beauty as I often find that what I may find aesthetically pleasing at any given time will generally be repugnant to extroverted herds. I'm more fascinated by older skin, for example. I enjoy the sensory stimulus of wrinkles, bumps, and whatnot. That's contrary to what any extroverted herd would hold as their standard.

Beauty, simply put, is in the eye of the beholder. It's what pleases the person individually as a stimulus they enjoy based upon their own personal biases. There's no Universal beauty at work, that's simply human culture doing what human culture does -- homogenising to the point of global recognisability.

Therefore, yes, if you were to ask ten extroverted people about beauty you'd likely get hte same result. If you were to ask ten autistic or introverted people, you'd get very different results. We know from recent studies that autistic people, introverts, LGBT folks, along with women, minority ethnicities, and those with disabilities are grossly underrepresented in any endeavour involving a study of people. The vast majority of those inducted will be straight, white, extroverted, not disabled, and male. If there are any women present, the statistically chance of them being white, extroverted, not disabled, and straight is almost 100 per cent.

Which makes you think, really, about many of the conclusions past studies have drawn.

Did you cite the Eiffel Tower as conforming to the golden ratio? In what non-Euclidean geometry does it even come close? It’s almost as wide as it is tall (and the fact that people often perceive it as much taller than wide is due to a pervasive optical illusion). Also, very few pieces of the Parthenon conform, mostly just the friezes. The overall structure? yeah, that’s not much closer to phi than the Eifel tower.
Where phi (Golden Ratio) comes up in nature, for example the ratio of chamber sizes in a chambered nautilus, it is due to fundamental geometric reasons, not because of any “fitness” and certainly not beauty. The fact that a person can quickly notice a flaw in a regular shape like a sunflower head is due to humans having excellent pattern matching skills, not because we can intuitively sense if something conforms to the Golden Ratio or not, and seeing a seed missing from the regular pattern of a seed head is no harder or easier if the spirals are relatively prime Fibonacci numbers or just a rectilinear grid in a 1 to 1 ratio.

One of the great challenges of our modern era is to design cities that are beautiful. For whatever reason, whether it’s politics or economics, some of the least qualified people have been allowed to build our cities and convince us that elevated highways and ugly skyscrapers are necessary and rows of cookie suburban homes or apartment block housing is acceptable.

A truly beautiful city would be 90% low rise buildings connected by beautiful sidewalks and multiple modes of transportation. Bikes, busses, taxis, trains, subways. Not just cars. Housing would be diverse also, from small colorful apartments like in northern Europe, to taller well designed Tokyo style apartment buildings. The 21st century should be the century of beautifully designed cities.

Whoever told them that stone blades were teardrop shaped simply for aesthetic reasons?! There are dozens practical reasons to make a teardrop shaped blade. It's the best way to make a point out of such fragile material, it gives you two slicing/sawing edges with very similar properties, it's easier to make two similar sides than purposely build two different ones when you're knapping, the oval shape of the back end reduces(disperses evenly if you will) the stresses on the tool and allow it to be attached to a variety of handles with similar ease, let along is easier to not cut yourself on if you're using the tool without a handle attached... I'm sure there are plenty I can't recall or don't even know. In fact, early stone tools aren't symmetrically shaped - they evolved to be after thousands of years. They should do their homework before they make statements like this.

The problem: If the appreciation of beauty is so advantageous to survival, why is it only humans who seem to have developed it? If it is so “deep rooted”, why haven’t all the other great apes developed aesthetics?

As you said, beauty is not simply a cultural phenomenon. Human infants, when played discordant or harmonious notes, prefer harmony, whereas other animals including great apes have no preference. Non-human animals can certainly be trained to put paint on a canvas, but are not inclined to create something classically beautiful.

All the other animals get by just fine in a much more dangerous world than us, without having a preference for aesthetics or a longing to create beauty. These animals must be able to interpret visual patterns just as well or better than us, but “liking” the pattern (for 99.99% of animal species) is not necessary for them to usefully process their visual input. The question of why humans “like” beauty remains unanswered.

You should have given Symmetry much more credit. Our whole Universe is built upon the principle of symmetry. In fact, think about it this way: when matter and antimatter connect, they collide, resulting in an annihilation. Now, our Universe could have been a result of asymmetry: of all matter and antimatter collision sequences, our Universe didn't receive it's counterpart.

So when it didn't, the symmetry carried on: similar galaxies -> similar stars -> similar planets -> life, including animals and plants -> micro life -> quantum particles. Symmetry is rooted into our existence. And the fact that life exists is all thanks to the greatest asymmetry the Existence ever experienced. Just look at our faces, they are just: an eye, an ear, an eyebrow, a part of a mouth and nose, all mirrored. We look like the Spore creatures, except for, we can't even realize it.

So when we see beautiful things, we react to their symmetry, the ultimate indicator of "how things should all be". But then, should they? Sometimes, I find it ironic how people hate each other because of their visual differences, unbeknownst to them that they are a product (life, human specifically) of asymmetry themselves

::DISCUSSION::

I take a lot of issue with this video. At 4:30 when it begins to talk about "bland, standardised boxes" - totally unscientific and ahistoric. Those "boxes" were part of an art movement called Brutalism, and at the time they were considered sleek, exciting, and futuristic. They have become undesirable over time due to their semantic association with poor people, who were more likely to live in social housing, which had been built by various governments at the peak of the Brutalism trend.

If you read contemporary media from the time, people thought those apartment buildings looked like hi-tech space stations. They represented an inspiring vision of a future that seemed closer than ever. Our modern dislike for them is semantic, not somehow biological, and decent research would have shown this.

As well, the early forays into "we like symmetry because it helped us survive in nature" - scientifically likely, but not proven and not proveable. Surprisingly shoddy work from a usually compelling channel.

Reminds me of what my stepfather told me about architecture and how he learned to design buildings (he was an architect/home designer).

Called it the SSS or 3S factor. The best looking buildings have these 3 things, according to him:

Simplicity. Too many peaks of a roof or too many dormers, or anything that makes a design complex fatigues the mind to think about.
Similarity. All window and door designs must be of the same series. Conflicting door/window/moulding/etc... designs make buildings more complex and fatiguing to think about, and unpleasant to look at.
Symmetry. If you have a dormer on the right side of a house, you have to have one on the left side. Roof peaks, if many, must be even increments smaller than the next (or larger). A design that isn't symmetrical isn't simple nor similar, as well. It is hard to think about and inherently unpleasing to look at.

are we wreathing

Spite of despondence, of the inhuman dearth
Of noble natures, of the gloomy days,
Of all the unhealthy and o’er-darkened ways   
 Made for our searching:
yes, in spite of all,
Some shape of beauty moves away the pall
From our dark spirits.
Such the sun, the moon,Trees old and young, sprouting a shady boon
For simple sheep; and such are daffodils   
With the green world they live in;
and clear rills
That for themselves a cooling covert make’
Gainst the hot season; the mid-forest brake,

And such too is the grandeur of the dooms

If beautiful things help us function better, then I see a correlation to the idea that plants should never be alone. Stay with me, it's simple.

The idea is that plants can "hear", meaning pick up vibrations in the air around them, when they are surrounded by other plants. A plant that is surrounded by other plants is likely in a fertile land were it is safe to grow and expand, whereas a plant that isn't surrounded by others is likely to be one of few survivors of bad times and is better of conserving energy instead of growing needlessly. They don't do this consciously, of course. It's simply the result of an adaptation over millions of years were those plants that followed a primitive pattern of this (even by chance) would reproduce their genome more successfully until we reach the current day complexity of the system.

Let's go back to people now. Given that we have an evolved sense of disgust towards things that are unhealthy to us, such as puke, poop or rotten food, it stands to reason that a similar selection has happened with us. When surrounded by things that disgust or bores us, we go into a survival mode, rather than bloom. That's more effective, hard times are to be endured after all. If on the other hand we are surrounded by strong symmetrical growth, bright fruits and a varied environment with plenty to look at (because there's plenty of things growing and living there!), we can assume that times are good and it's the right time to blossom. The brain releases joy and energy so we can frolic and mate.

If you're still here, thank you for reading.
Also, if anyone from the team is reading this, thank you for another good video!

You do not have to be so complicated.
We associate vegetation with a source of food. Having vegetation where we live makes us feel more safe because it instinctively tells us that we live in an environment that is rich with nutrients.
Living in an area where where no plants grows makes us feel unsafe. One part of us understands that there is a store nearby, while another part of the brain gets worried because you appear to live in a wasteland far from food.
A diversity of different plants tells your brain that there likely is a diversity of food, which means that there is a diversity of nutrients.
When I am really hungry it happens to me that my brain often has a hard time to accept that there is no food in a place where there are so many plants. I even tend to get more hungry when I see plants. It is as if my brain tells me.
This is why we find plants and things that reminds us of plants beautiful. This can be fractal patterns, but it can also be a wonky tree with long branches hanging down. A tree with long hanging branches can look that way because of how fruit may way it down.

We find things that reminds us of flowing water to be beautiful. We find things that can remind us of overhanging rocks/cliffs and caves to be beautiful because they can shelter you. We tend to find light sources beautiful because they make us see in the dark and gives us warmth.

Sorry for shouting, but something just clicked in my head that I've been struggling to figure out, for years. I have always wondered why we, as humans, consider tonal music pleasureable and atonal music stressful. I realized years ago that it must've had something to do with patterns- tonal music follows a strict pattern, regular intervals between notes in its scale; whils atonal music is atonal because it breaks the established pattern it makes, by having a note or several notes in a different interval. But I couldn't see why humans preferred patterns. Now I get it. Our brain is hardwired to recognize and prefer regularity, in fractals, symmetry, and repetition. One way or another, the mind evolved to treat sound like sight, the auditory patterns like visible ones.

The association between the golden ratio and beauty is unsubstantiated. It really is just a number. If you look hard enough, you can find any number in a picture. Saying that phi is the standard for all beauty is like saying that the triangle is symbol of all evil. You are as bad as people that believe in the Illuminati.

The connection between fractals and beauty is completely subjective. If you happen to like the visual pattern that a fractal creates, then sure, it's beautiful, but that's just you. No one else is obligated to find it beautiful.

As far as symmetry goes, you have to try to avoid all symmetry. You have to redesign the methods of production just to avoid creating a symmetry. Symmetry is just easy, and there is rarely a reason to go out of your way to make it more difficult. You've made half a tool by using a mold, why would you make a different mold to make the other half? That's just unnecessary work. Besides, your complaint with modern architecture is that it's too symmetric and lacks details.

There is no objective metric for beauty. Any claim that there is, is nothing more than new age bullshit from the 1800s.

I'd be interested to see more about that second hospital study - the one comparing the old style ward to the newly renovated one.

There's a lot of other factors going on there that'd be really hard to control for. Oxygen systems would be newer and less likely to have contaminants being breathed in. Plumbing equipment is newer. There's better design from a practical sense, probably more space for visitors, thus making visitors more common. These are all things that can be different because it's newer that have nothing to do with it being prettier.

There's also the question as to whether this is a case of happier patients healing better, or a case of happier staff providing better care, or both. This is less relevant because either way, making the hospital look nice is a good idea whether its to help motivate staff or to make the patients more comfortable, but still would be interesting to know.

By those early teardrop tools, you mean the Acheulean Handaxes, right? They're not our first tools - earlier tools tend to be a lot harder to recognize, though, because they're just an appropriately sized rock with a couple of rough breaks that form a cutting edge.

There's also a couple of interesting theories about the Acheulean Handaxes - at least one of the major sites they've found had far more of them than one could reasonably suggest was usable over the period of time they were found in the strata. (For the non archaeological - the deeper stuff is buried, the older it is, and if stuff is found at similar depth (and the soil above it is the same as the pattern elsewhere, as a disturbance indicates burial of something from more recent times) then it's roughly the same age.) At the time I was taking this archaeology class (which granted is now over a decade ago, rendering at least some of the theories I learned obsolete), one of the possible explanations for this oversized collection was that they were used ritually - for example, that one would make one as an engagement gift or the like. (That particular one requires the idea of monogamy to be quite a bit older than we have much evidence for, but it could just as easily be an indication of a less lasting form of interest, and that does a better job of explaining the amount of them, anyway.)

I might be different than most people, but I find a beauty in the mundane & plan things like plan walls made of concrete. I find myself staring at them looking at the little details seeing the crystal structure wondering who made the wall, the work put in, the story about the wall. I would go as far to say that I can stare at a clock for a time and think of the inner workings than the people who made it in the factory, than the history of the clock, and the individual revolution because of factory jobs. The same happens at any works I look at, in fact when I look at a person I start thinking about the processes that allow them to live, there neurons firing off causing reactions. Everything I strip down just like that & find beauty in everything. So, in my room with empty walls nothing decorative in it I’m happy & find beauty, but there’s one thing that brings me no such feeling of beauty. It’s all my thoughts, my Damon, I can’t stop thinking my mind never stops, and it takes all mystery out of life. For it gives a reason for everything, yet I feel there’s not point to anything. What I’m saying is when everything is understood nothing is beautiful or remarkable, and it all just blends into the rest. If there’s a moral message here it’s Life has not point, you have to make it. No one will hand you it, you’re going have to fight for it. Ironically I have to wait and be patient until my generations time to shape the world comes.

Have a nice day.

Wouldnt it be great if the world was a beautiful place full of happy people. Unfortunately, the fundamental principals of neurochemistry make it impossible. The emotions are essentially chemical messengers, and every feeling is merely a specific combination of these chemicals. While this is complex neurobiology which involves many different neurotransmitters and incredible precision. However, the essence of its principle is easy to understand. It has two type of functional chemicals, excitatory and inhibitory which are released in order of homeostatic plasticity. Which means it will always release neurotransmitters to maintain synaptic stability. For every excitatory chemical, it must release the equal number of inhibitory to sustain perceptional balance.
You know every beautiful emotion has its ugly counterpart, and this is for a reason. Because for every pleasant feeling, your brain will make you feel equally unpleasant, to maintain the balance.
If you have never been sad, how would you even know what happy feels?
If you have never suffered, you wouldn't be able to experience pleasure.

People could recover quicker in hospitals with art because it gives the impression of excess wealth/disposable funds. Art costs money, if a hospital can have art displayed everywhere then it give the impression of disposable funds ie if they can spend money on art, then all other facilities (equipment, paying for the best staff and so on) must be at the highest standard, lead g people to believe they are having a higher standard of care and recover quicker. Equally if the place is drab and delapodated it subconsciously gives the impression of incompetence (dispite the possibility that the staff and equipment are at the highest level)... However listening to music improves recovery by elevating mood so maybe its a simmalar response with art.

Beauty is universal. We don't have a great understanding for it yet, especially explicitly, but that doesn't mean that we can't show that it plays a more universal role than this video suggests. I encountered the following argument first in the book "The Beginning of Infinity" by the physicist David Deutsch, University of Oxford. So I will quote and highlight some key ideas of the relevant chapter.

"'Displace one note and there would be diminishment. Displace one phrase and the structure would fall.' That is how Mozart's music is described in Peter Shaffer's 1979 play Amadeus. This is reminiscent of the remark by John Archibald Wheeler with which this book begins, speaking of a hoped-for unified theory of fundamental physics: 'an idea so simple, so beautiful, that when we grasp it . . . how could it have been otherwise?' Shaffer and Wheeler were describing the same attribute: being hard to vary while still doing the job. In the first case it is an attribute of aesthetically good music, and in the second of good scientific explanations. And Wheeler speaks of the scientific theory as being beautiful in the same breath as describing it as hard to vary. Scientific theories are hard to vary because the correspond closely with an objective truth, which is independent of our culture, our personal preferences and our biological make-up. But what made Peter Shaffer think Mozart's music is hard to vary?" - p. 353
Let's take this to be our best understanding of beauty for the moment.

He goes on to give an example. Why are flowers beautiful? He asserts that they are beautiful because they had to solve a difficult problem. They needed to signal to bees, a far removed organizm on the tree of life. In order bridge a communication gap that far apart, flowers needed very effective encoding. One that would be hard to vary, namely beauty. Thinking about evolutions tendency to reward organisms that waste energy with a quick extinctions, why would flowers put so much effort into being beautiful? This chain of reasoning is so elegant that when I read it I thought . . . how could it have been otherwise?

As a modest Kurtzgesagt-fan, I would have appreciated this video more if it also highlighted the value of non-beautiful art. Art that haunts, gives new perspective. Artworks that make you shiver and feel human. I understand choosing this framework in context of the S&W beauty project. But in my eyes it educates a very narrow and simplistic view of art. Especially in a time where our personal believes get challenged less and less due to social pillarization, and boredom (which is not a bad thing!) is rare when the world is in the palm of your hand. Even though I was surprised by the beauty/health experiments, it feels like Kurzgesagt is saying: because we did it 10.000 years ago and it appears to be part of our instinct, it must be good for us. Which is a dangerous fallacy I think. And I hope Kurtzgesagt agrees on the latter. Lets not become lazy art-consumers, who just demand to be entertained by artworks. Looking at art is a dialogue, if a work not instantly pleasing, and we get bored, maybe we should try a litte harder. :)

5:42 I've only been in the hospital once for my own health, but many times when visiting my father. At around 12 I had contracted meningitis and was brought to a children's hospital to be treated. The walls were a warm color with some simple but pleasant patterns, and they had a store room full of donated movies and board games. The face masks the staff had worn were also colorful.

The hospitals my father had frequently found himself in were dull. Plain walls colored a dull white, floors with an ugly pattern, and all my father had to occupy himself with was basic cable and sleeping. Honestly, the aesthetic of such hosiptals seems very much to be "depressing".

Yeah, this didn't actually explain why beautiful things make us happy. The definition of beauty this video gives is "if you find it pleasant it's beautiful". It's circular logic. If it makes you happy it's beautiful, therefore we like beautiful things.

Symmetry is a heuristic that can easily reveal flaws and so has some utility. This doesn't fully explain why beauty makes us happy though. Many things are beautiful without symmetry and many things make us happy without beauty. Why are certain smells pleasurable or even beautiful?

My point is, we don't fully understand. Saying, beautiful things are things that make us happy, isn't giving us any explanatory power. Beauty isn't explained here; this video gives us some examples and sates our curiosity. This video doesn't explain beauty, it explains it away with great hubris.

I think this neglected the fundamental emergence of patterns causing beauty. We don't just find symmetry and fractals beautiful because of the nihilistic reason of "we evolved to associate them with good things", there is more to it than that. These patterns emerge out of large systems composed of simple parts which follow special rules that give rise to these patterns on a large scale. That's called emergence. The greatest example of emergence is human consciousness. And in the same way, our neurons have patterns in their arrangement, and when we experience things with patterns in them similar to the patterns inherently in our brains, we are happy. This doesn't happen because it has evolved to, it's simply that these patterns independently occur in different places, and some of those places are in our brains.

This video reminded me of a guest speaker we had recently at my university. She was a German theoretical physicist and she was talking about the basic premise of her book "Lost in Math: How Beauty Leads Physics Astray". Essentially, Dr. Hossenfelder argued that the pursuit of beauty has caught the academic community in a loop of poor research and dangerous mass ideology. She argued that physicists and other scientific fields alike ought to abandon the desire of beauty in their work. I think her lecture was a very interesting take on beauty and aligns well with this video.

Symmetrical Things actually carry less informations that asymmetrical things.
The Wine Glas at 00:58 for example can be mirrored and rotated and still has the same appearance. Therefore it is easier to describe its Form. Our Brains are lazy so they like this more.

Similar Things are true for right angles and straight surfaces. A straight surface or edge can be extruded without a change in Form. This is the reason most furnitures and rooms have a rectangular bounding box - you can move it around in your presumably rectangular room along the wall which would be much more complicated if the walls were curved.
Having a straight edge or surface is what is called 'translation invariance' in mathematics and is one of the less obvious spacial symmetries.

Now L-shaped rooms exist, but they are just a union of two rectangles and there is nothing new here but the right angles.
Right Angles are not easier to handle than others but they produce systems with less informations to handle. 3D or 2D Space is easiest described as a combination of 3 or 2 orthogonal vectors respectively.
If you use a set of 3 non-right angles to describe 3D space, there are a lot of coordinate conversions needed to predicting movement rather than just guessing the distances.
Your Brain needs to describe Space in some manner for you to be able to react to visual impulses quickly. It has been trained to do so and it prefers the fastest and easiest description.
So when you see non-straight angles your just want to make it less complicated to understand. \_

4:41 THIS DOES NOT MEAN that all intricate, detailed things are good and that all plain, boxy things are bad!

When you are designing the look of a thing or part of a thing, you must consider wether or not people should notice it, and how much time they should spend trying to visually absorb it. Too much visual information can quickly become overwhelming. This is why we have minimalism.

For example, websites and apps have trended towards minimalism for a long time now. Why? People are busy, we have short attention spans, and we want to focus on the CONTENT of the apps and sites we use, not on the interface; that's why web design elements like ugly drop shadows, saturated colors, heavy gradients, text effects, and animated banners have gone the way of the dinosaur; they are visually distracting. And such principles apply to ALL kinds of design, even urban planning.

If all buildings of a city were intricate, visually interesting works of art, it could easily turn into a distracting assault on your senses, and one which you would very quickly grow tired of.

I always found these concrete block buildings at least partially appealing. I mean, they are literarily mighty, towering over all constructs in the area (at least in the place I live in). They always filled me with a sense of pride (and accomplishment) of what modern society, via industry and progress can achieve. Of course that doesn't count for a two story cube with a few windows, a door and antenna slapped onto it but the mighty skyscrapers, the wide rows of living blocks, they give me a sense of safety, that I won't suffer the hardships of homelessnes and extreme powerty and even give me hope, that with such means like efficient architecture, stemming from the power of mass industry, humans might no longer suffer lack of base nescessities maybe even in my lifetime.

One thing I'd like to add, which is not really explored in this video, is how one should define beauty.

In my personal experience (as someone who has studied a bit (a lot) of everything from mathematics to the history of religion) I have come to define beauty as "the sentiment a human being gets, when they are presented with something that is simultaneously complex/rich and yet cognitively manageable/graspable".

Another way to frame this idea is that "beauty is geometric", in a much larger sense of the word. Here "geometric" includes everything from the geometry of ratios and waves that you find in harmonies and rhythms for music (and even storytelling, I'd wager); to the geometry of fractals, euclidean primitives and ratios in paintings and movie sequences; to the fractal harmonies of a great, complex meal; to the multiple reference game of a clever pun, acting on the "ecosystems" that our words actually are in our brains (analogy as the core of cognition, Hofstadter)); to the beauty of Euler formula and Euler's identity, in how they seem to encode the entirety of trigonometry and all its complexity in 2 lines that make everything so much simpler... It is an understanding of the word geometry as "the interplay of shapes in ANY form of mathematical space, in which an opposition between simplicity and complexity; consonance and dissonance; order and chaos; can take place". This definition applies well to every type of beauty I have felt personally. Beauty is what most naturally satisfies the human need for order, even (and especially) within a chaotic system.

*In a nutshell*, "feeling beauty", or rather, "taste", is using abstraction to manage complexity in sensory inputs with ease.

PS: Mathematics, being the ultimate quest for abstraction, is also the ultimate quest for beauty. But mathematics in school (limited to calculations and equations) are certainly not where you'd learn that; you'd learn to be convinced of the opposite in fact.

I think there is also a beauty in coincidences, such as watching a swan fly towards the sunset or listening to rain drops playing a soft melody on the leaves of a tree. Rare coincidences are the most beautiful ones. Such as watching an owner reunite with his dog after several years or  hearing an old song you had forgotten all about in a random café. The beauty of these coincidences is that they provide some sort of meaning to life - or at least the illusion of it. These coincidences are all natural and completely plausible, but they give us hope that perhaps there is a reason, a "higher power" if you will, not necessarily God/s, but something bigger, something  that makes it all worth it. Well, it's a comforting thought, at least.

Other people find familiar things beautiful, possibly because the feeling of comfort and safety it gives them when things aren't out of the ordinary. Yet other people find old things more beautiful that they have no direct connection to and that might be because they find the time before our era interesting.

Why this video is more beautiful?

I think this omits one particularly important factor, how beauty also comes from appreciation of practicality. If you understand how something works, how it's made, and how it's used, you're likely to perceive it very differently from someone who don't.
An example of this that I'm familiar with are medieval-type weapons as depicted in fantasy, compared to such weapons in real life. Fantasy weapons are often large, stylized, with complex silhouettes, dramatic reliefs built into their structure, lots of extrusions and spikes, wide, often very thick blades. This is what a lot of people think looks the best when it comes to weapons.
However, people who are interested in medieval history, and who may even practice the use of such weapons often find that the authentic weapons are far more beautiful, because they make sense, they find elegance in the straightforwardness and practical minimalism. A lot of these people would not only say that fantasy weapons don't look practical, but they often say that they find fantasy weapons ugly.

The stuff about golden ratio, fractals and symmetry is hypothetical and problematic. In nature there is an approximation or analogies to these things - but does not follow a  precise mathematical model. For example -fractals are infinitely complex patterns that are self-similar across different scales. That in it's true sense doesn't occur in nature. Nothing in nature really perfectly follows the golden ratio (much of the research behind it is done by non-scientists) or golden spiral, or is perfectly symmetric ( but approximately so). But yes, beauty matters and your video is brilliant and beautiful and amazing!

I disagree with your conclusions toward the end. You draw the conclusion that someone looking more at an object is more beautiful. You then extrapolate this to say that grey, standard brick buildings are boring and cause depression, etc.

I am heavily impacted by brutalist art and architecture. These things are beautiful in my eyes and have the precise impact you speak of. Many others enjoy the brutalist aesthetic and would consider it beautiful. There are other styles that are simple or could be considered drab or may cause general unhappiness for large populations, but this cannot and shouldn't be extrapolated to apply to every human on earth. We have different styles and forms for a reason. We can come together to recognise common beauty a lot of times, but we can also be extremely subjective about our tastes. I might have misinterpreted the end, and if I have someone will let me know probably, but it really seems like you are making beauty a very constant concept.

Question on the study done at the hospital with 2 wards: how do we know that the patients didn’t get better simply because it was a newer building? The doctors could have also been effected by the idea that one ward was newer than the other so they had access to better equipment. Whether that is true or not, it would make them feel more confident in their diagnoses, which would also play a role in patient happiness & recovery. The patients could also be effected by this, feeling more confident that they are in the modern building over the older building. Were there more tests done to mitigate the other factors? I’m not arguing against the ideas proposed in the video, I just want to make sure all variables are accounted for.

now the world is obsessed with rounded edges.

"elegant" water pitchers with not a single flat surface, want to put a mixing spoon on top of it for a short period? too bad, watch the spoon slide off and onto the ground.

The curved sides and elipse shape allows it to store less water while taking up twice the space.

The lid also has a reverse concave shape, meaning you have to struggle to put the lid on perfectly, also here is no "topping off" because water will always have a level surface.

Ah yes beauty "can" be an infection when its applied while sacrificing efficiency and utility.

Happiness is the successful state of life, pain is an agent of death. Happiness is that state of consciousness which proceeds from the achievement of one’s values. A morality that dares to tell you to find happiness in the renunciation of your happiness — to value the failure of your values — is an insolent negation of morality. A doctrine that gives you, as an ideal, the role of a sacrificial animal seeking slaughter on the altars of others, is giving you death as your standard. By the grace of reality and the nature of life, man — every man — is an end in himself, he exists for his own sake, and the achievement of his own happiness is his highest moral purpose.
But neither life nor happiness can be achieved by the pursuit of irrational whims. Just as man is free to attempt to survive in any random manner, but will perish unless he lives as his nature requires, so he is free to seek his happiness in any mindless fraud, but the torture of frustration is all he will find, unless he seeks the happiness proper to man. The purpose of morality is to teach you, not to suffer and die, but to enjoy yourself and live. ~ Ayn Rand

Art is a selective re-creation of reality according to an artist’s metaphysical value-judgments. Man’s profound need of art lies in the fact that his cognitive faculty is conceptual, i.e., that he acquires knowledge by means of abstractions, and needs the power to bring his widest metaphysical abstractions into his immediate, perceptual awareness. Art fulfills this need: by means of a selective re-creation, it concretizes man’s fundamental view of himself and of existence. It tells man, in effect, which aspects of his experience are to be regarded as essential, significant, important. In this sense, art teaches man how to use his consciousness. It conditions or stylizes man’s consciousness by conveying to him a certain way of looking at existence.     ~ Ayn Rand
